channel.title: Denver Homeless Out Loud
channel.description: Posts from Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: Arkins Encampment of 300 Houseless People Scheduled to be Swept...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Arkins Encampment of 300 Houseless People Scheduled to be Swept November 30th: WHERE the HECK are these 300 People Supposed to GO??&^?

Today the City posted the encampment at Arkins Court to be swept on Monday November 30th. There are around 300 houseless people living at this site. Residents have lived at this site consistently for over 9 months. The site surrounds a vacant lot of land and is next to the Cross Roads Shelter and the River on the other sides. For the past coup...le months police have been telling people who they sweep from other more visible downtown sites to go to Arkins. Now the City plans to come in and sweep them. To where???

Why not provide dumpsters with regular trash pick up? Why not provide port-a-potties (at least 1 for every 10 people)? And if not that...why not provide housing that residents of this camp can afford according to their info?

No, instead our City thinks sweeping 300 people to scatter to downtown blocks, down the river, or who knows where else is the answer.

Please come and support our unhoused community members at 29th and Arkins on Monday November 30th. Or come down before to show this community some love and support by bringing food, trash bags, or get to know some of the residents.

Bring the following things to assist residents:

-Truck, or any vehicle to help

-Carts

-Bungee Cords

-Rope

-Trash Bags

-Food

-Coffee/CoCo

-Water

Your assistance is much appreciated. Somewhere around 6am and all day help will likely be needed. Maybe even the next day too.

Toward Rights, Dignity and Housing…

item.title: Just because the permit as issued will not stop the NIMBY's...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Just because the permit as issued will not stop the NIMBY's who claim we can do better from sabotaging the effort. We need about 50 of these things and the NIMBY's will prevent even one from happening.

Colorado Village Collaborative

The zoning permit for the Safe Outdoor Space at 1373 N. Grant St. has been issued by Community Planning and Development.

Tomorrow's Community Information Meetin...g will provide a very important opportunity to share the facts about these critical projects, which are days away from launching.

item.title: Denver Homeless Out LoudSAFE: Safe Access for EveryoneThe Boulder Human Relations Commission unanimously voted for a resolution to, in part,...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out LoudSAFE: Safe Access for Everyone

The Boulder Human Relations Commission unanimously voted for a resolution to, in part, begin an investigation into possible human rights violations by the City ...against unhoused folks.

"City should match community’s compassion for the unhoused

By Darren O’connor

For those unfamiliar with the Boulder Human Relations Commission, it is empowered by ordinance to share community “suggestions on city policies with respect to social problems” and to “advise the council or manager on the social and human relations impact of proposals to be acted upon by the council or upon areas to which the council’s attention should be directed …” The HRC did just that with a unanimous vote to pass the following resolution on Nov. 16: “Whereas the City of Boulder does not allow unhoused individuals to self-shelter and at the same time, based on the triangulation of independent assessments of the City of Boulder unhoused populations, the City of Boulder does not provide nearly enough sheltering options to provide shelters for unhoused individuals, “Whereas it appears that the City of Boulder does not count nor maintain records on the actual number of unhoused in the City and individuals in the City who cannot appropriately use the existing City option for sheltering, “Whereas it appears that the City of Boulder consistently uses dehumanizing language in reference to underserved populations, “Whereas it appears that the City of Boulder has enacted policies and practices to exclude some unhoused individuals from receiving appropriate services, “Whereas it appears that the City of Boulder has propagated public relations messages misleading the public as to nature of the underserved population, “And, whereas it appears that the City of Boulder has not adequately pursued carefully documented options — such as tiny homes, safe parking, sanctioned encampments, and others — that could provide cost-effective options for underserved unhoused individuals, “The City of Boulder Human Relations Commission recommends that the Boulder City Council immediately appoint a diverse and representative (including three individuals with unhoused experience) oversight committee for City programs regarding the unhoused and formally begin an investigation into possible human rights violations by the City.”

This comes on the heels of the Metro Denver Homeless Initiative’s “State of Homelessness 2020 Report,” which “highlights two overarching trends in homelessness. (The f)irst, inherent in homelessness, is the racial inequity that must be addressed.”

This year’s Boulder Point In Time count showed Black people are 12 times more represented in the county’s unhoused population compared to the general population. For the region, indigenous people are seven times overrepresented. Combined with the fact that, per the MDHI report, “the leading cause of homelessness, not just in this region but around the country, is a lack of affordable housing,” we must stop repeat- ing fallacious claims that homelessness is the result of poor choices.

Throw in a pandemic and the situation is far worse, with a wide swath of Boulder’s residents facing an increased risk of eviction and homelessness and resulting health risks: risks that are also disproportionately greater for our Black and brown community members.

The HRC is right to sound the alarm about “possible human rights violations by the City.” We restrict access to basic shelter to people who haven’t lived here for six months, e.g., regardless of the vulnerability of such people. Multiple people are known to have already frozen to death since the first snow fell here, and the city’s policy is people experiencing homelessness are only allowed 30 days of severe weather shelter per season if, e.g., they have not lived here six months or are otherwise excluded from the precious few services that remain.

This exclusion of nonresidents flies in the face of the constitutional right to travel. Supreme Court Justice John Stevens ruled in 1999 that the Constitution provides “the right to enter one state and leave another, the right to be treated as a welcome visitor rather than a hostile stranger.” Justice William Brennan likewise held in 1974 that statutory prohibition of welfare benefits to residents of less than a year creates a classification that constitutes an invidious discrimination denying them equal protection of the laws. Sadly, enforcing such rights requires resources and access to the courts that are too often — just like shelter beds — unavailable to the poor and hurting.

Our Boulder community has recently shown that it is compassionate, donating greatly to food banks and to EFAA, and voting in favor of providing funding for legal assistance to those facing eviction with the successful No Eviction Without Representation ballot initiative.

Now that the Human Relations Commission has rung the bell regarding the City’s “propagat( ing) public relations messages misleading the public” about unhoused programs, that compassion remains as needed as ever.

Darren O’Connor is an attorney in Boulder, chairs the NAACP Boulder County Branch Criminal Justice Committee and is a regional vice president of the National Lawyers Guild.

Thomas John Hamilton, who is homeless, lies steps away from where boulder police cleared an illegal encampment along boulder Creek beneath the ninth Street bridge in February 2019.

Sam Lounsberry / File Photo"
https://www.dailycamera.com/…/guest-opinion-darren-oconnor…/

See MoreThe Human Relations Commission rang the bell regarding Boulder’s “public relations messages misleading the public” about homelessness programs,

item.title: You think there are a lot of tents now... Within 30 days of the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

You think there are a lot of tents now... Within 30 days of the new year there will be a tsunami of tent encampments is somethig significant is not done.
------------
“Without further policy intervention, we will likely have hundreds of thousands of Coloradans who owe back rent and can face immediate eviction or expulsion from their property if they aren’t able to tender full amounts of back rent,” said Jack Regenbogen, senior attorney with the Colorado Center on Law and Policy, who specializes in housing issues.

https://coloradonewsline.com/…/one-step-forward-and-two-st…/

item.title: Oh look at that... Vacant properties serving the greatest need....
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Oh look at that...

Vacant properties serving the greatest need. Solving a health and safety issue and reducing homelessness. Too bad our city gov't is more interested in campaign contributions than the public welfare. Their lack of response will prove it.

Not to weeks ago our city council voted down a budget amendment for a master lease program that would have allowed us to take advantage of our empty units here in Denver and make things better.

...

They consciously chose not to do better which means they chose to do worse.

https://abc7.com/homeless-coronavirus-and-california-el-…/…/

See MoreA group of homeless activists, known as Reclaiming Our Homes, are now legally living in state-owned homes that they once illegally occupied.

abc7.com

Homeless families who took shelter in vacant El Sereno homes can now legally live in them

A group of homeless activists, known as Reclaiming Our Homes, are now legally living in state-owned homes that they once illegally occupied.A group of homeless activists, known as Reclaiming Our Homes, are now legally living in state-owned homes that they once illegally occupied.

item.title: Seven activists were arrested at the SWEEP on 19th and Emerson...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Seven activists were arrested at the SWEEP on 19th and Emerson this morning. This camp was clean and had support from the housed neighbors across the street. The activists were there to support the camps desire to remain there. Many of them had been swept already 3 or 4 times. If you would like to donate funds for bonds please Venmo @lovelionhippopotamus Thank you! Onward towards dignity, rights, housing.

item.title: Don't forget first of 3 sweeps this week begins tomorrow. ...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Don't forget first of 3 sweeps this week begins tomorrow. It is unfortunate that they will sweep more times than people they house.

Denver Homeless Out Loud

THIRD SWEEP this week: 22nd and Bway to Stout on Thursday, in addition to Sweep of Encampment at 19th and Emerson Tuesday and 6th and Sherman Wednesday

Block to... Block to Block...No Housing.

Which one of these is illegal?? (see attached image)
FYI both of these are at 19th and Emerson - one of the sites slated to be swept next week


There are now THREE sweeps scheduled for this week.

The City just scheduled 22nd and Bway to Stout to be swept on Thursday the 19th. These particular blocks have been swept 6 times in the last 6 month. How the hell does this make any sense???

Tuesday November 17th the encampment on 19th and Emerson is scheduled to be swept by the City. On Wednesday November 18th an encampment right next to channel 7 news on 6th and Sherman is scheduled to be swept.

Moving people who have nowhere to go with no answer does not work.

Please come and support our unhoused community members at 19th and Emerson on Tuesday and 6th and Sherman on Wednesday AND 22nd and Bway/Stout on Thursday.

Bring the following things to assist residents:

-Truck, or any vehicle to help move

-Carts

-Bungee Cords

-Rope

-Trash Bags

-Food

-Coffee/CoCo

-Water

Your assistance is much appreciated! Somewhere around 6:30am and all morning help will likely be needed.

Toward Rights, Dignity and Housing…

Contact:

info@denverhomelessoutloud.org

720-940-5291
